choices.text: Net sensitivity is increased and Net specificity is decreased
Net sensitivity is decreased and Net specificity is increased
Net sensitivity remains the same and Net specificity is increased

questions.text: A Hemoccult test with sensitivity of 70% and specificity of 75% is applied for detecting Colon cancer. If Hemoccult test is negative, no further testing is done. If test is positive the individual will have a second sample tested with Hemoccult II test. If second sample also tests positive for blood, they will be referred for more extensive evaluation. The effect on net sensitivity and specificity of this method of screening is
questions.solution:
• Testing in Series/ Sequential/two stage testing
    • A Population subjected to one screening test followed by a second screening test
    • Second test applied to those whom test positive on 1 st test
  • Testing in Parallel.
    • Also called Simultaneous testing
    • A Population subjected two(more)screening tests at the same time
    • Each of the individual subjected to all tests

choices.text: INH prophylaxis to a baby born to mother with TB

questions.text: Which of the following is not primary prevention

choices.text: Measuring what it is suppose to measure
Correctly predicting the presence of disease
Correctly excluding the possibility of disease
Yielding same reading or value when repeated under same condition

questions.text: Reliability of a test means
questions.solution:
• VALIDITY: Ability of a test to detect truth
  • Validity has 2 components
    • Sensitivity
    • Specificity

RELIABILITY: Yielding same reading or value when repeated under same condition

  • Also known as Repeatability, Precision, Reproducibility, Consistency

questions.text: A physical examination was used to screen for breast cancer in 2500 women with biopsy proven adenocarcinoma of breast and in 5000 age and race matched control women. The results of physical examination were positive in 1000 cases and 800 control women. The sensitivity and positive predictive value of physical examination was respectively
In case of Baye's theorem for assessing PPV the numerator consists of
questions.solution:
Baye’s theorem formula:

PPV=              Sensitivity X Prevalence                 X 100                    

               (Sensitivity X Prevalence)+(1-specificity)(1-prevalence)

 

NPV=            Specificity X (1- Prevalence )                X 100                    

    {Specificity X(1- Prevalence)}+{(1-sensitivity) X prevalence}

questions.text: All the following are quantitative variables except
questions.solution:
• Variables are classified as
    1. Qualitative/Categorical variable
    2. Quantitative variable

Qualitative subclassified into again three

  • Nominal (denoting names)- eg: gender,blood group
  • Ordinal (having order) eg: APGAR score, TNM staging
  • Binomial (two outcomes) eg: no of failures/successes, dead/alive

Quantitative subclassified into two

  • Continuous variable (having decimals)- height, weight, temperature scales
  • Discrete variable (only whole numbers)- No.of children, no: of states in a country

choices.text: Trend of a variable over a period of time
Mean & Median values of a given data

questions.text: A Scatter diagram is drawn to study
questions.solution:
A Scatter diagram is drawn to study correlation between two quantitative variables

eg: age and height.

Exposure variable is plotted along X axis and outcome variable along Y axis

questions.text: The FBS levels for a group of diabetics is found to be normally distributed with a mean of 105mg per 100ml of blood& a SD of 10mg/100ml. 95% of diabetics will have their FBS levels within the limits of
questions.solution:
In a normal distribution 95% of values in data set lies between Mean ± 2 SD

So 95% of diabetics will have a value between 105 ± 20= 85 t0 125 mg%

questions.text: For testing the statistical significance of difference in heights of school children among three socioeconomic groups, the most appropriate statistical test is

  • In a table, (c-1) (r-1)

questions.text: The correlation between Smoking and Lung cancer in a study was found to be 1.5. This indicates
questions.solution:
• Correlation : Shows Relationship between 2 quantitative variables
  • Correlation coefficient(r): measures degree or strength of association
  • r lies between -1 to +1
  • 1 means perfect correlation and cant exceed 1
  • 0 means no correlation
  • Represented by scatter diagram

choices.text: Start ART first followed by ATT
Start ATT first followed by ART

questions.text: A patient diagnosed to have both HIV and TB, which of the drug regimen should be followed
questions.solution:
The provision of HIV ART therapy and anti TB drug treatment at the same time involves a number of potential difficulties including

  • Cumulative drug toxicities
  • Drug - drug interactions
  • A high pill burden
  • The Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS)

As per the latest NACO guidelines, for an HIV and TB coinfected patientsà  start Anti Tubercular Treatment first thereafter initiate ART between 2 weeks and 2 months

choices.text: Artesunate 50mg for 3 days + Sulfadoxine - Pyrimethamine (500 & 25mg) single dose + Primaquine for 14 days
Artesunate alone 4mg/kg if patient were pregnant and in second trimester
Artesunate 200mg + Sulfadoxine - Pyrimethamine (750 & 37.5mg) daily for 3 days
Artesunate 4mg/kg for 3 days + Sulfadoxine - Pyrimethamine (25 & 1.25mg/kg) single dose + Primaquine 0.75 /kg single dose

questions.text: A patient was admitted to a government hospital with and microscopically confirmed Plasmodium falciparum infection. Which one of the following treatments is indicated?
questions.solution: Artemisinin Combination Therapy (ACT) should be given to all the confirmed P. falciparum cases found positive by microscopy or RDT. This is to be accompanied by single dose of primaquine (0.75 mg/kg body weight) on Day 2. The ACT recommended in the National Program all over India (except in northeastern states ) is artesunate (4 mg/kg body weight) daily for 3 days and sulfadoxine (25 mg/kg body weight) -pyrimethamine (1.25 mg/kg body weight) [AS+SP] on Day 0. For north eastern states recommended ACT in national drug policy is fixed dose combination (FDC) of Artemether-lumefantrine (AL)

questions.text: Obesity means BMI more than
questions.solution:
• India reworks obesity guidelines as
  • BMI of 23kg/m2 – Overweight (previously 25)
  • BMI of 25kg/m2 - Obesity (previously 30)

questions.text: Vector involved in Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is
questions.solution: Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever is a viral haemorrhagic fever usually transmitted by hard ticks. It can also be contracted through contact with viraemic animal tissues (animal tissue where the virus has entered the bloodstream) during and immediately post-slaughter of animals. CCHF outbreaks constitute a threat to public health services as the virus can lead to epidemics, has a high case fatality ratio (10-40%), potentially results in hospital and health facility outbreaks, and is difficult to prevent and treat.

questions.text: Blindness caused by opacities in the lens comes under
questions.solution:
Types of blindness based on causes

  1. Type Ià Blindness caused by obvious lesions of cornea
  2. Type IIà Blindness caused by lens opacities
  3. Type IIIà Blindness caused by other known or identified causes
  4. Type IVà Blindness caused by undetermined or unspecified causes

questions.text: In Plasmodium vivax malaria, the drug Primaquine is given for a period of
questions.solution: Positive P. vivax cases should be treated with chloroquine in full therapeutic dose of 25 mg/kg divided over three days. Vivax malaria relapses due to the presence of hypnozoites in the liver. The relapse rate in vivax malaria in India is around 30%. For its prevention, primaquine may be given at a dose of 0.25 mg/kg daily for 14 days under supervision. Primaquine is contraindicated in G6PD deficient patients, infants and pregnant women.

questions.text: MBER(Monthly Blood Examination Rate) norms laid down by NVBDCP for Malaria fever surveillance during transmission season is
questions.solution: The fever rate in the community fluctuates widely from month to month and year to year.  For accurate estimates of malaria endemicity, the blood smear examination rate specially the Monthly Blood Examination Rate (MBER) rate should be equal to fever rate of the month in the community. The MBER norms of 0.8 percent during non-transmission season and 1.2 to 1.8 percent during transmission season were laid down in the NVBDCP

questions.text: Sero surveillance helps to identify pattern of
questions.solution:
• Sero surveillance will help to find out levels of IgM and IgG
  • IgM denotes recent infection
  • IgG denotes past infection

questions.text: New TB Definitions.
questions.solution:
NEW definitions in TB control

Recurrent TB case – A TB patient previously declared as successfully treated (cured/treatment completed) and who is subsequently found to be microbiologically confirmed TB case is a recurrent TB case. (Previously called relapse.)

Treatment after loss to follow-up – A TB patient previously treated for TB for one month or more and who was declared lost to follow-up in their most recent course of treatment and subsequently found microbiologically confirmed TB cases. (Previously called treatment after default )

choices.text: Either parenteral quinine or parenteral artemesinin

questions.text: DOC for severe and complicated Pf malaria
questions.solution:
Severe malaria is an emergency and treatment should be given promptly. Parenteral artemisinin derivatives or quinine should be used as specific antimalarial therapy. Intravenous route should be preferred over intramuscular. Once the patient can tolerate oral therapy or after at least 24 hours of parenteral therapy, further follow-up treatment should be as below. Patients receiving artemisinin derivatives should get full course of oral ACT. However, ACT containing mefloquine should be avoided in cerebral malaria due to neuropsychiatric complications. Patients receiving parenteral quinine should also be treated with full course of oral ACT.

In first trimester of pregnancy, parenteral quinine is the drug of choice. However, if quinine is not available, artemisinin derivatives may be given to save the life of mother. In second and third trimester, parenteral artemisinin derivatives are preferred

questions.text: Which test use whole blood as sample in detection of TB
questions.solution: Interferon gamma release assays (IGRAs) are blood-based tests intended for diagnosis of latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI). IGRAs offer logistical advantages and are supposed to offer improved specificity over the tuberculin skin test (TST).

questions.text: Which of the following does not belong to Step 3 procedure under the WHO STEP wise approach for surveillance (STEPS) of Non-Communicable Disease risk factors
questions.solution:
The WHO STEP wise approach to noncommunicable disease (NCD) risk factor surveillance is designed to help countries build and strengthen their surveillance capacity. The STEPS Instrument covers three different levels of 'steps' of risk factor assessment. These steps are:

  • Step 1: Risk factors assessed using Questionnaire- Age, Family history, Physical activity, Nutrition etc
  • Step 2: Risk factors assessed using Physical measurements like Height, Weight, Waist circumference, BP
  • Step 3: Risk factors assessed using Biochemical measurements- Fasting Blood sugar, Blood  cholesterol , Urine sugar etc

questions.text: Web based program for monitoring TB
questions.solution:
NI-KSHAY-(Ni=End, Kshay=TB) is the web enabled patient management system for TB control under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP). It is developed and maintained by the Central TB Division (CTD), Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India, in collaboration with the National Informatics Centre (NIC), and the World Health Organization Country office for India.

Nikshay is used by health functionaries at various levels across the country both in the public and private sector, to register cases under their care, order various types of tests from Labs across the country, record treatment details, monitor treatment adherence and to transfer cases between care providers. It also functions as the National TB Surveillance System and enables reporting of various surveillance data to the Government of India.

questions.text: HIV Sentinel surveillance is done
questions.solution:
Objective of Sentinel Surveillance is

  1. To assess the level of HIV infection among general population and high risk groups
  2. To understand the trend of HIV epidemic

Here Blood samples are collected from sentinel sites from high risk groups and Antenatal every 2 years

questions.solution:

  • DNA PCR using Dried Blood Spots (DBS)
  • Infants can be tested as early as six weeks of age

questions.text: All diseases are covered under Indradanush except
questions.solution: The goal of Mission Indradhanush is to ensure minimum 90% immunisation with all available vaccines for children up to two years of age and pregnant women. The diseases being targeted in Mission Indradhanush are diphtheria, whooping cough, tetanus, poliomyelitis, tuberculosis, measles, meningitis and Hepatitis B. In addition to these, vaccines for Japanese encephalitis and Haemophilus influenzae type B are also being provided in selected states.

questions.text: Pediatric Pulmonary TB is suspected in a child in all the following conditions except
questions.solution:
TB is suspected in a child under the following conditions:

  • Persistent fever > 2 weeks
  • Cough > 2 weeks
  • Loss of weight
  • No weight gains

-    History of contact with TB case

questions.text: XDR TB means resistance to
questions.solution: Extensively drug-resistant TB (XDR TB) is a rare type of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR TB) that is resistant to isoniazid and rifampin, plus any fluoroquinolone and at least one of three injectable second-line drugs (i.e., amikacin, kanamycin, or capreomycin ).

questions.text: Minimum gap between two live vaccines
questions.solution: Two or more injectable or nasally administered live vaccines if not administered on the same day should be separated by at least 4 weeks to minimize the potential risk for interference. If 2 such vaccines are separated by <4 weeks, the second vaccine administered should not be counted and the dose should be repeated at least 4 weeks later. On the day a live injectable or intranasal vaccine will be administered, providers should ensure that no live injectable or intranasal vaccine was given in the previous 28 days. (CDC gudelines)

choices.text: Case control study requires more time than cohort
Cohorts are chosen based on exposure
Case control used for rare diseases

questions.text: Which of the following is not the true difference between case control and cohort?
questions.solution:
Cohort studies

Advantages.

  1. Starts with exposure to outcome
  2. Provide a clear temporal sequence of exposure and disease.
  3. Give an opportunity to study multiple outcomes related to a specific exposure.
  4. Permit calculation of incidence rates (absolute risk) as well as relative risk.
  5. Good to study rare exposures.

Disadvantages.

  1. Not suited for the study of rare diseases
  2. Not suited when the time between exposure and disease manifestation is very long,
  3. Drop outs are possible
  4. Expensive to carry out
  5. Time consuming study design

Case-control studies

Advantages.

  1. Permit the study of rare diseases.
  2. Can be done in relatively short time periods.
  3. Relatively inexpensive as compared to cohort studies.
  4. Can study multiple potential causes/Risk factors of disease.

Disadvantages.

  1. Recall bias is possible
  2. By definition, concerned with one disease only.
  3. Cannot provide information on incidence rates of disease.
  4. Choice of appropriate control group may be difficult.

choices.text: Indian life expectancy used as standard
One DALY means one lost year of healthy life

questions.text: DALY true is
questions.solution:
DALY is Disability Adjusted Life Years

It is one of the disability indicators

Measure of burden of disease in a defined population and effectiveness of interventions

Expresses years lost to premature deaths and years lived with disability adjusted for its severity

questions.text: James Lind is known for
questions.solution:
• James Lind was a Navy doctor. His experiment to find cause behind scurvy is considered as the first clinical trial conducted
  • He divided the 12 sick sailors with an unknown sickness (later found to be scurvey)into six pairs, and provided each of them with a different supplement in their diet: cider, vitriolic elixir (diluted sulfuric acid), vinegar, sea water, two oranges and a lemon, or a purgative mixture.
  • Following this experiment two sailors who took the fruit recovered from survey

questions.text: Simplest measure of mortality
questions.solution:
Crude death rate – simplest mortality indicator

Formula=Total no: of deaths  X 1000

                   Mid Year Population

questions.text: For calculation of incidence denominator is taken as
questions.solution:
Incidence

Is a morbidity indicator

No.of new cases of a disease during a specified time interval X 1000

      Total population at risk during same interval

questions.text: Relative risk is calculated in
questions.solution:
Outcome measures in Cohort study areas follows

  1. Incidence
  2. Relative risk (RR)/ Risk Ratio
  3. Attributable risk (AR)
  4. Population attributable risk (PAR)

Relative Risk

  • How many times higher is the chance of developing the disease among exposed compared to non exposed
  • Formula

Incidence among exposed  X 100

Incidence among non exposed

choices.text: Unequal distribution of prognostic factors between arms

questions.text: Randomization is useful to eliminate
questions.solution:
Uses of randomization:

  • Helps to eliminate selection bias
  • Makes treatment and control arm comparable in terms of prognostic factors and confounders

questions.text: Isolation period should bee
questions.solution:
• Isolation 

Separation for period of communicability of infected persons or animals from others in such places and conditions to prevent transmission of infectious agent from those infected to those susceptible

  • Quarantine 

Restriction of movement of apparently healthy people who have been exposed to a case of communicable disease for a period equivalent to longest IP of the disease

questions.text: PQLI lies between
questions.solution:
PQLI values ranges from 0 to 100

HDI values ranges from 0 to 1

questions.text: In a village with population of 5000, 50 people have a disease and 10 of them died. What is case fatality rate
questions.solution:
Case fatality Rate=

Total no: of deaths due to a particular disease X100

Total no: of cases due to same disease

(10/50) X 100= 20%

  • IndicatesàKilling power of disease and is Related to virulence of organism

questions.text: In a population of 5000. no: of new cases of TB is 500; old cases in same population are 150. what is the prevalence of TB
questions.solution:
Prevalence =

Total no: of cases due to a particular disease X1000

Mid Year Population/ Total Population

Total cases= 500+150= 650

Total population =5000

Prevalence = 650/5000 X1000= 130/1000 population = 13%

questions.text: 20 pregnant women were asked about h/o smoking when they came for regular antenatal visit and then followed up to see how many of them had LBW babies. What is the type of study?
questions.solution: Study design is Cohort as it starts with exposure (smokers and non smokres) and prospective follow up to measure the outcome (Low birth weight babies ) among exposed and non exposed

questions.text: First case that came to notice of physician is
questions.solution:
First case occurred in an area is Primary case. It may even go unnoticed

First case noticed- Index case

questions.text: Secular trend is called
questions.solution: Long term fluctuation is also known as Secular trend

choices.text: Increase in both incidence and prevalence
Decrease in both incidence and prevalence

questions.text: A drug which reduces mortality but does not cure a disease, will gradually lead to
questions.solution:
Factors which increase prevalence->Incidence (new cases getting added) and increase in duration of disease

Factors which decrease prevalence->increase in Cure rate and Mortality

questions.text: Which is not a mortality indicator
questions.solution:
Years of potential life lost- measures premature death

Life expectancy- Positive mortality indicator

IMR- Mortality rate in Infants

Prevalence and Incidence – Morbidity indicator

questions.text: Which of the following is best to compare the vital statistics of countries
questions.solution: Age standardised death rate is the death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution. It will help to compare vital data between countries

questions.text: A couple has 4 children, all unvaccinated for measles. A child got measles on 5 August 2015. Two other children developed measles by 15 August 2015. Secondary attack rate is
questions.solution:
Secondary Attack Rate

  • No: of exposed susceptible persons developing the disease within range of IP following exposure to primary case

 

No: of exposed persons developing the disease within range of IP X 100

Total no: of exposed susceptible contacts

 

  • Primary case is always excluded from both numerator and denominator

No: of secondary cases=2

Primary case =1

No: of exposed susceptible= 3 (4-1)

SAR= 2/3 X 100= 66%

questions.text: A study was done in 3 states to see the mean blood pressure in each community. Health workers were assigned and they visited each house in the three communities. Mean blood pressure in each community was found and compared. What type of study design is represented here?
questions.solution:
Study design is Cross sectional as it is a one-time examination by a survey to assess the average blood pressure in three villages. It is done at a point in time (at present)

Case control study is a retrospective study design

Cohort is a prospective study design
